p: Phenotypic screening refers to the nascent methodology for the biological screening of the chemical entities to assess their therapeutic effects. It is not a target- based strategy but involves detailed cell-based studies ( Aulner et al., 2019). The phenotypic screening was done to identify different small molecules which depict antibiofilm and antifilamentation activity against C. albicans. This study leads to the identification of about 2293 compounds from the chemical library of the National Cancer Institute which were categorized into three sets- (i) NCI Natural set, Out of all the compounds present in this set six hits were confirmed against C. albicans biofilm formation. These include -Trichoderonin 27; Nanaomycin 28; Rapamycin 29; Anisomycin 30; Valinomycin 31 and Bacitracin 32. Three of these molecules (Trichoderonin, Nanaomycin, Rapamycin) showed inhibition of both filamentation and biofilm formation while the rest three showed inhibition against biofilm formation.
